index.title: Home
index.content:
Home

Welcome! This is the UIengine Test Project. It contains some sample pages to showcase and also test the basic functionality provided by the UIengine.

You can use this project as an overview to look at certain features, like documentation written in markdown or the design token templates.

The sample project pattern styles are provided by Semantic UI. This is just to make them look a bit nicer and give you an idea of how to integrate assets in the templates.

Please ignore the ‚ÄúTest Cases‚Äù part, as it only contains some pages that exist for testing.

patterns.title: Pattern Library
patterns.content:
Pattern Library

The test project pattern styles are provided by Semantic UI.

documentation/development.title: Contributing
documentation/development.content:
Contributing

  • Development Workflow
  • Important Notes and Guidelines

Development workflow

üì¶ Setup

Dependencies are managed via Yarn. Once you have Yarn installed and this repo cloned, you can setup the packages:

yarn install

üõ† Development

Create a build and rebuild on file change.

yarn start

üö• Tests

Basic linting is done in the project root:

yarn lint

Run the tests:

yarn test

Run the tests continually on file change:

yarn test-watch

Tests with coverage info:

yarn cover

üöÄ Release

Build and publish new release:

yarn release

This command also accepts the lerna publish options.

Notes

Here are some things to keep in mind and guidelines for working on the UIengine codebase.

Coding standards

This project uses the JavaScript Standard Style. We try to keep it as functional as possible, so we are using Ramda a lot.

Public functions in core

  • Are always async
  • First argument should always be the state

Emojis in commit messages

Please make sure that your commit messages start with a somehow fitting emoji.

Reward yourself

We are using All Contributors to show who helped the project. In case you have contributed and are missing on that list, feel free to add yourself!

documentation/getting-started.title: Getting Started
documentation/getting-started.content:
Getting Started

This guide helps you to get started quickly with the uiengine. We will use npx to run the locally installed uiengine in the following.

npx is bundled with npm since v5.2.0. It allows us to easily run locally installed packages like uiengine, which must have been installed globally otherwise, setup in the $PATH variable or called with a path prefix.

üèé TL;DR ‚Äì¬†The fast lane

The following process is also covered in the introduction videos:

Initialize a new npm project:

mkdir uiengine-demo && cd uiengine-demo && npm init

You will be prompted for the project information. To skip the prompt and use some empty defaults, run npm init -y instead.

Next, install the UIengine development dependencies locally:

npm install @uiengine/core @uiengine/adapter-html --save-dev

Now initialize an empty UIengine demo project:

npx uiengine init --demo

Serve the project locally and watch for changes:

npx uiengine build --serve --watch

Congratulations! üéâ Now you have a basic UIengine demo project running.

In the following you can read about the steps in more detail.

üì¶ How to install the UIengine?

The UIengine should be installed as a dependency for a project.

npm install --save-dev @uiengine/core

You will also need at least one adapter to render your components. Here we will use the HTML adapter as an example, so go ahead and install it:

npm install --save-dev @uiengine/adapter-html

See the adapter docs for details and a list of available adapters.

üî∞ How to setup the UIengine in a project?

You should initialize the UIengine in the directory that also contains your package.json.

npx uiengine init

This command creates a config file named uiengine.config.js, which contains the basic configuration. It also creates the folder pages containing a README.md file. This is the page file for the index page of the documentation.

You can also use the demo flag when initializing the project:

npx uiengine init --demo

This generates some demo pages and components to give a basic overview for some of the features. Beware: It uses the HTML adapter, hence the components are very simplistic.

‚öôÔ∏è How to configure the project?

The config file uiengine.config.js contains the basic configuration for your project. If you generated the file with the init command it contains comments for the individual sections. See the config documentation for details.

‚ûï How to create a component?

To generate the basic files of a component you can use the component command:

npx uiengine component COMPONENT_ID

This will also generate a default variant named after the component. In case you want to directly add some variants, you can list them like so:

npx uiengine component COMPONENT_ID VARIANT_1 VARIANT_2 VARIANT_3

‚ûï How to create a variant?

A variant needs at least a file to render. You create a variant by adding a file renderable by one of the configured adapters to the variants directory of a component.

To render a variant, we also need a layout. The npx uiengine init command created a basic html layout file in src/templates/uiengine.html. It includes the <!-- uiengine:content --> comment, which will be replaced with the HTML of the rendered variant. You can go ahead and extend the layout to fit your needs and include the correct HTML and style and script references.

This layout file is just there to get you started. Feel free to change its content and use an other adapter to fit your projects needs.

‚ûï How to create a page?

To generate the basic files and folders of a page you can use the page command:

npx uiengine page PAGE_ID

This generates a README.md and a page.config.js file inside the folder matching the page id in you pages source directory. In case you want to directly add some pages, you can list them like so:

npx uiengine page PAGE_1_ID PAGE_2_ID PAGE_3_ID

Say you would like to create pages for grouping your components with the Atomic Design Methodology:

npx uiengine page atoms molecules organisms templates pages

‚ú® How to generate the project?

The site can be generated with the following command:

npx uiengine build

To rebuild on file change you can also leverage the watch mode:

npx uiengine build --watch

You can also spawn a server for the generated site:

npx uiengine build --serve

The watch and serve options can be combined, which makes a good development environment:

npx uiengine build --watch --serve

Under the hood BrowserSync is used to provide serving and watching the files. For information on how to configure the server and pass additional options, see the configuration documentation.

documentation/tokens/icons.title: Icons
documentation/tokens/icons.content:
Icons are used to provide additional meaning or in places where text label doesn‚Äôt fit. They communicate messages at a glance and draw attention to important information.

Each icon ships in SVG format.

Usage

The recommended way to use the project icons is to reference them from the sprite:

<svg viewBox="0 0 1 1" class="c-icon [additional-classes]">
  <use xlink:href="[icon-name]"></use>
</svg>

Styling

You can easily style the icons using CSS:

.c-icon {
  width: 2rem;
  height: 2rem;
  color: $brand-primary;
}

tokens.text: Just some custom sample text to show the usage of this font.

font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-weight: 800;

variants.raw:
<template>
  <my-label v-bind="$props" />
</template>

<script>
import MyLabel from '../label.vue'

export default {
  name: 'MyLabelVariant',

  components: {
    MyLabel
  },

  props: {
    id: {
      type: String,
      required: true
    },

    title: {
      type: String,
      required: true
    }
  }
}
</script>

title.description: The id of the referenced form element

variants.title: Form
variants.raw:
include /modules/form/form.pug
include /modules/formfield/formfield.pug
include /elements/input/input.pug
include /elements/label/label.pug

+form("#")
  +formfield()
    +label("first_name", "First name")
    +input("first_name", "person[first_name]")(placeholder="First Name")
  +formfield()
    +label("last_name", "Last name")
    +input("last_name", "person[last_name]")(placeholder="Last Name")

  <!-- omit:code:start -->
  +formfield()
    +label("username", "Username")
    +input("username", "person[username]")
  <!-- omit:code:end -->

  <!-- omit:preview:start -->
  +formfield()
    +label("password", "Password")
    +input("password", "person[password]", "Password")
  <!-- omit:preview:end -->

formfield.title: Formfields
formfield.content:
Formfields

Formfields contain the input and an optional label.
